Diversity of MIMO Multihop Relay Channels—Part I: Amplify-and-Forward

Sheng Yang and Jean-Claude Belfiore Manuscript submitted to the IEEE Transactions on Information Theory. The authors are with the Department of Communications and Electronics, École Nationale Supérieure des Télécommunications, 46, rue Barrault, 75013 Paris, France (e-mail: syang@enst.fr; belfiore@enst.fr).
Abstract

In this two-part paper, we consider the multiantenna multihop relay channels in which the source signal arrives at the destination through N𝑁N independent relaying hops in series. The main concern of this work is to design relaying strategies that utilize efficiently the relays in such a way that the diversity is maximized. In part I, we focus on the amplify-and-forward (AF) strategy with which the relays simply scale the received signal and retransmit it. More specifically, we characterize the diversity-multiplexing tradeoff (DMT) of the AF scheme in a general multihop channel with arbitrary number of antennas and arbitrary number of hops. The DMT is in closed-form expression as a function of the number of antennas at each node. First, we provide some basic results on the DMT of the general Rayleigh product channels. It turns out that these results have very simple and intuitive interpretation. Then, the results are applied to the AF multihop channels which is shown to be equivalent to the Rayleigh product channel, in the DMT sense. Finally, the project-and-forward (PF) scheme, a variant of the AF scheme, is proposed. We show that the PF scheme has the same DMT as the AF scheme, while the PF can have significant power gain over the AF scheme in some cases. In part II, we will derive the upper bound on the diversity of the multihop channels and show that it can be achieved by partitioning the multihop channel into AF subchannels.

Index Terms:
Multihop, multiple-input multiple output (MIMO), relay channel, amplify-and-forward (AF), diversity-multiplexing tradeoff (DMT).

I Introduction and Problem Description

Wireless relaying systems have lots of advantages over traditional direct transmission systems. For example, the periphery can be extended by the relays and the coverage of the existing network can be improved. Using relays can also shorten the point to point transmission distance, which results in lower power (interference) level or in higher throughput. Furthermore, all these benefits can be realized in a more flexible, easier and cheaper to deploy network.

Recently, there has been a boosting interest in the cooperative diversity with which the spatial diversity is exploited through distributed relays. Since the work of Sendonaris et al.  [1, 2] that introduced the notion of cooperative diversity, a number of relaying protocols have been proposed (see, e.g., [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10]). Most of the previous works consider the single-antenna two-hop relay channel where the source signal is able to arrive at the destination through at most two hops, i.e., the source-relay hop and relay-destination hop. In an N𝑁N-relay channel, it is shown that a diversity order of N+1𝑁1N+1 (respectively, N𝑁N) can be achieved with (respectively, without) the direct source-destination link.

In this work, we consider the MIMO multihop channel model without direct source-destination link. That is, the source signal arrives at the destination through N𝑁N independent relaying hops in series. In the two-hop case, our model is reduced to the model studied by Jing and Hassibi [6]. The central concern of our work is to design relaying strategies that utilize efficiently the relays in such a way that the diversity is maximized. In part I, we focus on the amplify-and-forward (AF) strategy with which the relays simply scale the received signal and retransmit it. The main contributions of this paper are as follows.

  1. 1.

    First, we obtain the diversity-multiplexing tradeoff (DMT) of the Rayleigh product channel, whose channel matrix is a product of independent Gaussian matrices. It turns out that each Rayleigh product channel belongs to an equivalent class that is uniquely represented by the so-called minimal form. Furthermore, based on the closed-form expression of the DMT, we derive a recursive DMT characterization that have very simple and intuitive interpretation.

  2. 2.

    Then, it is shown that the AF multihop channel is actually equivalent to the Rayleigh product channel. We can thus identify the two channels and all previously established results apply to the multihop channel. Therefore, the diversity properties of the AF multihop channel in terms of the number of hops and the number of antennas in each node are completely characterized. We also propose the project-and-forward (PF) scheme, a variant of the AF scheme, in the case where full antenna cooperation is possible. It is shown that, although the PF scheme has the same DMT as the AF scheme, the PF can have significant power gain over the AF scheme in some cases.

  3. 3.

    Finally, it is pointed out that using less relaying antennas improve the power gain by avoiding the hardening of relayed noise, a particular phenomenon in the AF multihop channel. And reducing the number of transmit antennas can lower significantly the coding delay and decoding complexity. The vertical channel reduction result gives exactly the minimum number of antennas we need at each node to keep the same DMT.

In part II of this paper, we will derive an upper bound on the diversity of the multihop channels and show that the AF scheme is not optimal in general. Then, we will proposed both distributed and non-distributed schemes that achieve the upper bound. The main idea is to partition the multihop channel into AF subchannels.

The rest of part I is organized as follows. Section II presents the channel model and the AF scheme with some basic assumptions. The Rayleigh product channel is introduced and studied in section III. Results concerning the AF and PF schemes are collected in section IV. In section V, numerical results on some typical scenarios are shown. Finally, we draw a brief conclusion in section VI. For fluidity of the presentation, all demonstrations of proofs are delayed to the appendices.

II System Model

II-A Channel Model

The considered N𝑁N-hop relay channel model is illustrated in Fig. ​1, where there are one source (node #00), one destination (node #N𝑁N), and N−1𝑁1N-1 clusters of intermediate relays. Each cluster is logically seen as a node (node #111 to node #N−1𝑁1N-1) that is equipped with multiple antennas (nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} antennas for node #i𝑖i). We assume that node #i𝑖i can only hear node #i−1𝑖1i-1. Mathematically, we have

where 𝑯i∈ℂni×ni−1subscript𝑯𝑖superscriptℂsubscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖1{\boldsymbol{H}}_{i}\in\mathbb{C}^{n_{i}\times n_{i-1}} is the channel between node #i−1𝑖1i-1 and node #i𝑖i; 𝒙i,𝒚i∈ℂni×1subscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝒚𝑖superscriptℂsubscript𝑛𝑖1{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i},{\boldsymbol{y}}_{i}\in\mathbb{C}^{n_{i}\times 1} is the transmitted and received signal at node #i𝑖i; 𝒛∈ℂni×1∈𝒞​𝒩​(0,𝐈)𝒛superscriptℂsubscript𝑛𝑖1𝒞𝒩0𝐈{\boldsymbol{z}}\in\mathbb{C}^{n_{i}\times 1}\in\mathcal{C}\mathcal{N}\!\left(0,\mathbf{I}\right) is the additive white Gaussian noise at node #i𝑖i. The channels 𝑯isubscript𝑯𝑖{\boldsymbol{H}}_{i}’s are independent and modeled as Rayleigh quasi-static channels, i.e., the entries of 𝑯isubscript𝑯𝑖{\boldsymbol{H}}_{i} are i.i.d. 𝒞​𝒩​(0,1)𝒞𝒩01\mathcal{C}\mathcal{N}\!\left(0,1\right) distributed and do not change during the transmission of a data frame. For simplicity, it is assumed that the intermediate nodes work in full-duplex111The assumption is merely for simplicity of notation. As one can easily verify, since no cross-talk between different channels, the half-duplex constraint is directly translated to a reduction of degrees of freedom by a factor of two and does not impact the relaying strategy. This is achieved by letting all even-numbered (respectively, odd-numbered) nodes transmit (respective, receive) in even-numbered time slot and received (respective, transmit) in odd-numbered time slots. mode and all transmitting nodes are subject to the same short-term power constraint

where the expectation is taken on the noises. All terminals are supposed to have full channel state information (CSI) at the receiver and no CSI at the transmitter. From now on, we denote the channel as a (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) multihop channel.

II-C Diversity-Multiplexing Tradeoff

In this paper, we use the diversity-multiplexing tradeoff (DMT) as the performance measure.

Definition 1 (Multiplexing and diversity gains[11])

The multiplexing gain r𝑟r and diversity gain d𝑑d of a fading channel are defined by

r≜limSNR→∞R​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)log⁡𝖲𝖭𝖱andd≜−limSNR→∞log⁡Pout​(𝖲𝖭𝖱,R)log⁡𝖲𝖭𝖱formulae-sequence≜𝑟subscript→SNR𝑅𝖲𝖭𝖱𝖲𝖭𝖱and≜𝑑subscript→SNRsubscript𝑃out𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑅𝖲𝖭𝖱r\triangleq\lim_{{\scriptscriptstyle\textsf{SNR}}\to\infty}\frac{R({\mathsf{SNR}})}{\log{\mathsf{SNR}}}\quad\textrm{and}\quad d\triangleq-\lim_{{\scriptscriptstyle\textsf{SNR}}\to\infty}\frac{\log P_{\textrm{out}}({\mathsf{SNR}},R)}{\log{\mathsf{SNR}}}

where R​(𝖲𝖭𝖱)𝑅𝖲𝖭𝖱R({\mathsf{SNR}}) is the target data rate and Pout​(𝖲𝖭𝖱,R)subscript𝑃out𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑅P_{\textrm{out}}({\mathsf{SNR}},R) is the outage probability for a target rate R𝑅R. A more compact form is

Pout​(𝖲𝖭𝖱,r​log⁡𝖲𝖭𝖱)≐𝖲𝖭𝖱−d.approaches-limitsubscript𝑃out𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑟𝖲𝖭𝖱superscript𝖲𝖭𝖱𝑑P_{\textrm{out}}({\mathsf{SNR}},r\log{\mathsf{SNR}})\doteq{\mathsf{SNR}}^{-d}. (3)

Note that in the definition we use the outage probability instead of the error probability, since it is shown in [11] that the error probability is dominated by the outage probability in the high SNR regime and that the thus defined DMT is the best that we can achieve with any coding scheme.

Lemma 1

The DMT of a nt×nrsubscript𝑛tsubscript𝑛rn_{\text{t}}\times n_{\text{r}} Rayleigh channel is a piecewise-linear function connecting the points (k,d​(k))𝑘𝑑𝑘(k,d(k)), k=0,1,…,min⁡(nt,nr)𝑘01…subscript𝑛tsubscript𝑛rk=0,1,\ldots,\min{(n_{\text{t}},n_{\text{r}})}, where

d​(k)=(nt−k)​(nr−k).𝑑𝑘subscript𝑛t𝑘subscript𝑛r𝑘d(k)=(n_{\text{t}}-k)(n_{\text{r}}-k).

III The Rayleigh Product Channel

As it is shown in the next section, the AF multihop channels are intimately related to a more general Rayleigh product channel defined below. In this section, we investigate the Rayleigh product channel and provides some basic results on the diversity. Let us begin by the following definitions.

Definition 2 (Rayleigh product channel)

Let 𝐇i∈ℂni−1×nisubscript𝐇𝑖superscriptℂsubscript𝑛𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑖{\boldsymbol{H}}_{i}\in\mathbb{C}^{n_{i-1}\times n_{i}}, i=1,2,…,N𝑖12…𝑁i=1,2,\ldots,N, be N𝑁N independent complex Gaussian matrices with i.i.d. zero mean unit variance entries. A (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) Rayleigh product channel is a nN×n0subscript𝑛𝑁subscript𝑛0n_{N}\times n_{0} MIMO channel defined by

𝒚=𝖲𝖭𝖱n1​⋯​nN​𝚷​𝒙+𝒛𝒚𝖲𝖭𝖱subscript𝑛1⋯subscript𝑛𝑁𝚷𝒙𝒛{\boldsymbol{y}}=\sqrt{\frac{{\mathsf{SNR}}}{n_{1}\cdots n_{N}}}{\boldsymbol{\Pi}}\,{\boldsymbol{x}}+{\boldsymbol{z}} (4)

where 𝚷≜𝐇1​𝐇2​⋯​𝐇N≜𝚷subscript𝐇1subscript𝐇2⋯subscript𝐇𝑁{\boldsymbol{\Pi}}\triangleq{\boldsymbol{H}}_{1}{\boldsymbol{H}}_{2}\cdots{\boldsymbol{H}}_{N}; 𝐱𝐱{\boldsymbol{x}} is the transmitted signal with power constraint 𝔼​(‖𝐱‖2)≤nN𝔼superscriptnorm𝐱2subscript𝑛𝑁\mathbb{E}(\left\|{{\boldsymbol{x}}}\right\|^{2})\leq n_{N}; 𝐳∈ℂn0×1∼𝒞​𝒩​(0,𝐈)𝐳superscriptℂsubscript𝑛01similar-to𝒞𝒩0𝐈{\boldsymbol{z}}\in\mathbb{C}^{n_{0}\times 1}\sim\mathcal{C}\mathcal{N}\!\left(0,\mathbf{I}\right) is the additive white Gaussian noise; 𝖲𝖭𝖱𝖲𝖭𝖱{\mathsf{SNR}} is the receive signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) per receive antenna.

Definition 3 (Exponential equivalence)

Two channels are said to be exponentially equivalent or equivalent if their eigen-exponents have the same asymptotical joint pdf.

Let 𝒏~bold-~𝒏\boldsymbol{\tilde{n}} be the ordered version of 𝒏𝒏{\boldsymbol{n}} with n~N≥n~N−1≥⋯≥n~0subscript~𝑛𝑁subscript~𝑛𝑁1⋯subscript~𝑛0\tilde{n}_{N}\geq\tilde{n}_{N-1}\geq\cdots\geq\tilde{n}_{0}.

Definition 4 (Reduction of Rayleigh product channel)

A (m0,m1,…,mk)subscript𝑚0subscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑘(m_{0},m_{1},\ldots,m_{k}) Rayleigh product channel is said to be a reduction of a (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) Rayleigh product channel if 1) they are equivalent, 2) k≤N𝑘𝑁k\leq N, and 3) (m0,m1,…,mk)⪯(n~0,n~1,…,n~k)precedes-or-equalssubscript𝑚0subscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑘subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛1…subscript~𝑛𝑘(m_{0},m_{1},\ldots,m_{k})\preceq(\tilde{n}_{0},\tilde{n}_{1},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{k}). In particular, if k=N𝑘𝑁k=N, then it is called a vertical reduction. Similarly, if m~i=n~i,∀i∈[0,k]formulae-sequencesubscript~𝑚𝑖subscript~𝑛𝑖for-all𝑖0𝑘\tilde{m}_{i}=\tilde{n}_{i},\ \forall\,i\in[0,k], it is a horizontal reduction.

Definition 5 (Minimal form)

(n~0,n~1,…,n~N∗)subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛1…subscript~𝑛superscript𝑁(\tilde{n}_{0},\tilde{n}_{1},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{N^{*}}) is said to be a minimal form if no reduction other than itself exists. Similarly, it is called a minimal vertical form (respectively, minimal horizontal form) if no vertical (respectively, horizontal) reduction other than itself exists. A channel is said to have order N∗superscript𝑁N^{*} if its minimal form is of length N∗+1superscript𝑁1N^{*}+1.

Theorem 2

A (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) Rayleigh product channel can be reduced to a (n~0,n~1,…,n~k)subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛1…subscript~𝑛𝑘(\tilde{n}_{0},\tilde{n}_{1},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{k}) channel if and only if

k​(n~k+1+1)≥∑l=0kn~l.𝑘subscript~𝑛𝑘11superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝑘subscript~𝑛𝑙k(\tilde{n}_{k+1}+1)\geq\sum_{l=0}^{k}\tilde{n}_{l}. (8)

In particular, it can be reduced to a Rayleigh channel if and only if

n~2+1≥n~0+n~1.subscript~𝑛21subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛1\tilde{n}_{2}+1\geq\tilde{n}_{0}+\tilde{n}_{1}. (9)

This theorem implies that (n~0,n~1,…,n~N∗)subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛1…subscript~𝑛superscript𝑁(\tilde{n}_{0},\tilde{n}_{1},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{N^{*}}) is a minimal form if there exists no k<N∗𝑘superscript𝑁k<N^{*} such that (8) is satisfied. One can also verify that if (n~0,n~1,…,n~N∗)subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛1…subscript~𝑛superscript𝑁(\tilde{n}_{0},\tilde{n}_{1},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{N^{*}}) is a minimal horizontal form of (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}), then 1) it is also a minimal form; and 2) the minimal vertical form is (n~0,n~1,…,n~N∗,n¯,…,n¯)subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛1…subscript~𝑛superscript𝑁¯𝑛…¯𝑛(\tilde{n}_{0},\tilde{n}_{1},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{N^{*}},\bar{n},\ldots,\bar{n}) where

n¯=⌈∑l=0N∗n~iN∗−1⌉.¯𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑙0superscript𝑁subscript~𝑛𝑖superscript𝑁1\bar{n}=\left\lceil\frac{\sum_{l=0}^{N^{*}}\tilde{n}_{i}}{N^{*}}-1\right\rceil. (10)

Furthermore, note that the order N∗superscript𝑁N^{*} is upper-bounded by n~0subscript~𝑛0\tilde{n}_{0} because (8) is always satisfied with k=n~0𝑘subscript~𝑛0k=\tilde{n}_{0}. In other words, the length of the minimal form is bounded by n~0+1subscript~𝑛01\tilde{n}_{0}+1. In particular, the minimal form of a (1,n1,…,nN)1subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(1,n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) Rayleigh product channel is always (1,n1)1subscript𝑛1(1,n_{1}), i.e., a 1×n~11subscript~𝑛11\times\tilde{n}_{1} or n~1×1subscript~𝑛11\tilde{n}_{1}\times 1 Rayleigh channel.

Theorem 3

Two Rayleigh product channels are equivalent if and only if they have the same minimal form.

From this theorem, we deduce that the class of exponential equivalence is uniquely identified by the minimal form. Therefore, N∗superscript𝑁N^{*} can also be defined as the order of the class.

III-B Characterization of the Diversity-Multiplexing Tradeoff

From theorem 1, we can derive the DMT of a Rayleigh product channel.

Theorem 4 (Direct characterization)

The DMT of a Rayleigh product channel (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) is a piecewise-linear function connecting the points (k,d​(k))𝑘𝑑𝑘(k,d(k)), k=0,1,…,nmin𝑘01…subscript𝑛k=0,1,\ldots,n_{\min}, where

d​(k)=∑i=k+1nminci𝑑𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑘1subscript𝑛subscript𝑐𝑖d(k)=\sum_{i=k+1}^{n_{\min}}c_{i} (11)

with cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} defined by (7).

Since the DMT is a bijection of the coefficients cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}’s, all results obtained previously apply to the DMT and two Rayleigh product channels are equivalent if and only if they have the same DMT. Hence, the exponential equivalence class is also the DMT-equivalence class. However, unlike the eigen-exponent, the DMT provides an insight on the diversity performance of a channel (or a scheme) for different multiplexing gain. Note that, despite the closed-form nature of the characterization (11), it is lack of intuition. That is why we search for an alternative characterization.

Theorem 5 (Recursive characterization)

The DMT d​(k)𝑑𝑘d(k) defined in (11) can be alternatively characterized by

R1(N)(k):d(n0,…,nN)(k)\displaystyle R_{1}^{(N)}(k)~{}:\quad d_{(n_{0},\ldots,n_{N})}(k) =d(n0−k,…,nN−k)​(0),∀k;absentsubscript𝑑subscript𝑛0𝑘…subscript𝑛𝑁𝑘0for-all𝑘\displaystyle=d_{(n_{0}-k,\ldots,n_{N}-k)}(0),\quad\forall k; (12)
R2(N)(i):d(n0,…,nN)(0)\displaystyle R_{2}^{(N)}(i)~{}:\quad d_{(n_{0},\ldots,n_{N})}(0) =minj≥0⁡d(n0,…,ni)​(j)+d(j,ni+1,…,nN)​(0),∀i;absentsubscript𝑗0subscript𝑑subscript𝑛0…subscript𝑛𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑗subscript𝑛𝑖1…subscript𝑛𝑁0for-all𝑖\displaystyle=\min_{j\geq 0}d_{(n_{0},\ldots,n_{i})}(j)+d_{(j,n_{i+1},\ldots,n_{N})}(0),\quad\forall i; (13)
R3(N)(i,k):d(n0,…,nN)(k)\displaystyle R_{3}^{(N)}(i,k)~{}:\quad d_{(n_{0},\ldots,n_{N})}(k) =minj≥k⁡d(n0,…,ni)​(j)+d(j,ni+1,…,nN)​(k),∀i,k.absentsubscript𝑗𝑘subscript𝑑subscript𝑛0…subscript𝑛𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑗subscript𝑛𝑖1…subscript𝑛𝑁𝑘for-all𝑖𝑘\displaystyle=\min_{j\geq k}d_{(n_{0},\ldots,n_{i})}(j)+d_{(j,n_{i+1},\ldots,n_{N})}(k),\quad\forall i,k. (14)

The recursive characterization has an intuitive interpretation as follows. Let us consider k𝑘k as a “network flow” between the source and the destination and d​(k)𝑑𝑘d(k) as the minimum “cost” to limit the flow to k𝑘k (the flow-k𝑘k event). In particular, the maximum diversity d​(0)𝑑0d(0) can be seen as the “disconnection cost”. First, R1​(k)subscript𝑅1𝑘R_{1}(k) says that the most efficient way to limit the flow to k𝑘k is to keep a (k,k,…,k)𝑘𝑘…𝑘(k,k,\ldots,k) channel fully connected and to disconnect the (n0−k,n1−k,…,nN−k)subscript𝑛0𝑘subscript𝑛1𝑘…subscript𝑛𝑁𝑘(n_{0}-k,n_{1}-k,\ldots,n_{N}-k) residual channel, as shown in Fig. ​3(a). Then, R2​(i)subscript𝑅2𝑖R_{2}(i) suggests that in order to disconnect a (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) channel, if we allow for j𝑗j flows from the source to some node i𝑖i, then the (j,ni+1,…,nN)𝑗subscript𝑛𝑖1…subscript𝑛𝑁(j,n_{i+1},\ldots,n_{N}) channel from the j𝑗j “ends” of the flows at node i𝑖i to the destination must be disconnected. The idea is shown in Fig. ​3(b). Obviously, the most efficient way is such that the total cost is minimized with respect to j𝑗j. This interpretation sheds lights on the typical outage event of the Rayleigh product channel. In the trivial case of N=1𝑁1N=1 (the Rayleigh channel), there is only one subchannel. The typical and only way for the channel to be in outage is that all the paths are bad, i.e., the disconnection cost is n~0×n~1subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛1\tilde{n}_{0}\times\tilde{n}_{1}. In the non-trivial cases, there are more than one subchannels and thus the typical outage event is not necessarily for one of the subchannels being totally bad. The mismatch of two partially bad subchannels can also cause outage. In a more general way, the flow-k𝑘k event takes place when both the flow-j𝑗j event in the (n0,…,ni)subscript𝑛0…subscript𝑛𝑖(n_{0},\ldots,n_{i}) channel and the flow-k𝑘k event in the (j,ni+1,…,nk)𝑗subscript𝑛𝑖1…subscript𝑛𝑘(j,n_{i+1},\ldots,n_{k}) channel happen at the same time. We can verify that (R1​(k),R3​(i,k))subscript𝑅1𝑘subscript𝑅3𝑖𝑘(R_{1}(k),R_{3}(i,k)) is equivalent to (R1​(k),R2​(i))subscript𝑅1𝑘subscript𝑅2𝑖(R_{1}(k),R_{2}(i)). Note that the DMT is completely characterized by these relations in a recursive manner.

The following corollaries conclude some properties of the DMT of the Rayleigh product channel.

Corollary 1 (Monotonicity)

The DMT is monotonic in the following senses :

  1. 1.

    if (n1,0,n1,1,…,n1,N)⪰(n2,0,n2,1,…,n2,N)succeeds-or-equalssubscript𝑛10subscript𝑛11…subscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝑛20subscript𝑛21…subscript𝑛2𝑁(n_{1,0},n_{1,1},\ldots,n_{1,N})\succeq(n_{2,0},n_{2,1},\ldots,n_{2,N}), then

    d(n1,0,…,n1,N)​(r)≥d(n2,0,…,n2,N)​(r),∀r;subscript𝑑subscript𝑛10…subscript𝑛1𝑁𝑟subscript𝑑subscript𝑛20…subscript𝑛2𝑁𝑟for-all𝑟d_{(n_{1,0},\ldots,n_{1,N})}(r)\geq d_{(n_{2,0},\ldots,n_{2,N})}(r),\quad\forall\,r;
  2. 2.

    if {n1,0,n1,1,…,n1,N1}⊇{n2,0,n2,1,…,n2,N2}subscript𝑛20subscript𝑛21…subscript𝑛2subscript𝑁2subscript𝑛10subscript𝑛11…subscript𝑛1subscript𝑁1\{n_{1,0},n_{1,1},\ldots,n_{1,N_{1}}\}\supseteq\{n_{2,0},n_{2,1},\ldots,n_{2,N_{2}}\}, then

    d(n1,0,…,n1,N1)​(r)≤d(n2,0,…,n2,N2)​(r),∀r.subscript𝑑subscript𝑛10…subscript𝑛1subscript𝑁1𝑟subscript𝑑subscript𝑛20…subscript𝑛2subscript𝑁2𝑟for-all𝑟d_{(n_{1,0},\ldots,n_{1,N_{1}})}(r)\leq d_{(n_{2,0},\ldots,n_{2,N_{2}})}(r),\quad\forall\,r.
Corollary 2

Let us define

pk≜{n~0k=0,∑l=0kn~l−k​n~k+1k=1,…,N−1,−∞k=N.≜subscript𝑝𝑘casessubscript~𝑛0𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝑘subscript~𝑛𝑙𝑘subscript~𝑛𝑘1𝑘1…𝑁1𝑘𝑁p_{k}\triangleq\begin{cases}\tilde{n}_{0}&k=0,\\ \sum_{l=0}^{k}\tilde{n}_{l}-k\tilde{n}_{k+1}&k=1,\ldots,N-1,\\ -\infty&k=N.\end{cases} (15)

Then,

d(n0,…,nN)​(r)=d(n~0,…,n~k)​(r),for​r≥pk.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑subscript𝑛0…subscript𝑛𝑁𝑟subscript𝑑subscript~𝑛0…subscript~𝑛𝑘𝑟for𝑟subscript𝑝𝑘d_{({n}_{0},\ldots,{n}_{N})}(r)=d_{(\tilde{n}_{0},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{k})}(r),\quad\text{for}\ r\geq p_{k}.

While corollary 1 implies that d​(r)≤d(n~0,…,n~k)​(r)𝑑𝑟subscript𝑑subscript~𝑛0…subscript~𝑛𝑘𝑟d(r)\leq d_{(\tilde{n}_{0},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{k})}(r) in a general way, corollary 2 states precisely that d​(r)𝑑𝑟d(r) coincides with d(n~0,…,n~k)​(r)subscript𝑑subscript~𝑛0…subscript~𝑛𝑘𝑟d_{(\tilde{n}_{0},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{k})}(r) for r≥pk𝑟subscript𝑝𝑘r\geq p_{k}.

Corollary 3 (Upper bound and lower bound)
n~0​n~12<d​(0)≤n~0​n~1subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛12𝑑0subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛1\frac{\tilde{n}_{0}\tilde{n}_{1}}{2}<d(0)\leq\tilde{n}_{0}\tilde{n}_{1}

where d​(0)𝑑0d(0) is known as the maximum diversity gain.

From (7) and (11), the upper bound is obtained by setting n~2subscript~𝑛2\tilde{n}_{2} large enough and the lower bound is obtain by setting n~2=…=n~Nsubscript~𝑛2…subscript~𝑛𝑁\tilde{n}_{2}=\ldots=\tilde{n}_{N}. This corollary implies that the diversity of a Rayleigh product channel can always be written as d​(0)=a​n~0​n~1𝑑0𝑎subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛1d(0)=a\tilde{n}_{0}\tilde{n}_{1} with a∈(0.5,1]𝑎0.51a\in(0.5,1]. Hence, the diversity “bottleneck” of the Rayleigh product channel 𝚷𝚷{\boldsymbol{\Pi}} is not necessarily one of the subchannels 𝑯isubscript𝑯𝑖{\boldsymbol{H}}_{i}, but rather the virtual n~0×n~1subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛1\tilde{n}_{0}\times\tilde{n}_{1} Rayleigh channel. On the other hand, the maximum diversity gain is always strictly larger than n~0​n~12subscript~𝑛0subscript~𝑛12\frac{\tilde{n}_{0}\tilde{n}_{1}}{2}, independent of the value N𝑁N. In order to illuminate the impact of N𝑁N on the DMT, let us consider the symmetric case.

Corollary 4 (Symmetric Rayleigh product channels)

When n0=n1=…=nN=nsubscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁𝑛n_{0}=n_{1}=\ldots=n_{N}=n, we have

d​(k)=(n−k)​(n+1−k)2+a​(k)2​((a​(k)−1)​N+2​b​(k))𝑑𝑘𝑛𝑘𝑛1𝑘2𝑎𝑘2𝑎𝑘1𝑁2𝑏𝑘d(k)=\frac{(n-k)(n+1-k)}{2}+\frac{a(k)}{2}((a(k)-1)N+2b(k)) (16)

where a​(k)≜⌊n−kN⌋≜𝑎𝑘𝑛𝑘𝑁a(k)\triangleq\left\lfloor\frac{n-k}{N}\right\rfloor and b​(k)≜(n−k)​mod​N≜𝑏𝑘𝑛𝑘mod𝑁b(k)\triangleq(n-k)\ \text{mod}\ N.

In the symmetric case, on one hand, we observe that the DMT degrades with N𝑁N. On the other hand, from (16), the degradation stops at N=n𝑁𝑛N=n and we have

d​(k)=(n−k)​(n+1−k)2𝑑𝑘𝑛𝑘𝑛1𝑘2d(k)=\frac{(n-k)(n+1-k)}{2}

for N≥n𝑁𝑛N\geq n. This can also be deduced from theorem 2 applying which we get that the order of all symmetric Rayleigh product channel with N>n𝑁𝑛N>n is N∗=nsuperscript𝑁𝑛N^{*}=n. Therefore, we lose less than half of the diversity gain due to the product of Rayleigh MIMO channels, in contrast to the intuition that the maximum diversity gain could degrade to 111 with N→∞→𝑁N\to\infty. As an example, in Fig. ​4, we show the DMT of the 2×2222\times 2 and 5×5555\times 5 Rayleigh product channels with different values of N𝑁N.

III-C General Rayleigh Product Channel

In fact, we can define a more general Rayleigh product channel as

𝚷g≜𝑯1​𝑻1,2​𝑯2​⋯​𝑯N−1​𝑻N−1,N​𝑯N.≜subscript𝚷𝑔subscript𝑯1subscript𝑻12subscript𝑯2⋯subscript𝑯𝑁1subscript𝑻𝑁1𝑁subscript𝑯𝑁{\boldsymbol{\Pi}}_{g}\triangleq{\boldsymbol{H}}_{1}{\boldsymbol{T}}_{1,2}{\boldsymbol{H}}_{2}\cdots{\boldsymbol{H}}_{N-1}{\boldsymbol{T}}_{N-1,N}{\boldsymbol{H}}_{N}. (17)
Theorem 6

The general Rayleigh product channel is equivalent to

  1. 1.

    a (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) Rayleigh product channel, if all the matrices 𝑻i,i+1subscript𝑻𝑖𝑖1{\boldsymbol{T}}_{i,i+1}’s are square and their singular values satisfy σj​(𝑻i,i+1)≐𝖲𝖭𝖱0approaches-limitsubscript𝜎𝑗subscript𝑻𝑖𝑖1superscript𝖲𝖭𝖱0\sigma_{j}({\boldsymbol{T}}_{i,i+1})\doteq{\mathsf{SNR}}^{0}, ∀i,jfor-all𝑖𝑗\forall i,j;

  2. 2.

    a (n0,n1′,…,nN−1′,nN)subscript𝑛0subscriptsuperscript𝑛′1…subscriptsuperscript𝑛′𝑁1subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n^{\prime}_{1},\ldots,n^{\prime}_{N-1},n_{N}) Rayleigh product channel, with ni′subscriptsuperscript𝑛′𝑖n^{\prime}_{i} being the rank of the matrix 𝑻i,i+1subscript𝑻𝑖𝑖1{\boldsymbol{T}}_{i,i+1}, if the matrices 𝑻i,i+1subscript𝑻𝑖𝑖1{\boldsymbol{T}}_{i,i+1}’s are constant.

Therefore, the results obtained previously for the Rayleigh product channel can be applied to the general one.

IV Amplify-and-Forward Multihop Channels

Using the results from the previous section, we are going to analyze the performance of the AF scheme presented in section II, in terms of the DMT.

IV-A Equivalence to the Rayleigh Product Channel

With the AF scheme, the end-to-end equivalent MIMO channel is

𝒚N=(∏i=1N𝑫i​𝑯i)​𝒙1+∑j=1N(∏i=jN𝑯i+1​𝑫i)​𝒛jsubscript𝒚𝑁superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑫𝑖subscript𝑯𝑖subscript𝒙1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖𝑗𝑁subscript𝑯𝑖1subscript𝑫𝑖subscript𝒛𝑗{\boldsymbol{y}}_{N}=\left(\prod_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{D}}_{i}{\boldsymbol{H}}_{i}\right){\boldsymbol{x}}_{1}+\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\prod_{i=j}^{N}{\boldsymbol{H}}_{i+1}{\boldsymbol{D}}_{i}\right){\boldsymbol{z}}_{j} (18)

where for the sake of simplicity, we define ∏i=1N𝑨i≜𝑨N​⋯​𝑨1≜superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑨𝑖subscript𝑨𝑁⋯subscript𝑨1\prod_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{A}}_{i}\triangleq{\boldsymbol{A}}_{N}\cdots{\boldsymbol{A}}_{1} for any matrices 𝑨isubscript𝑨𝑖{\boldsymbol{A}}_{i}’s; 𝑯N+1≜𝐈≜subscript𝑯𝑁1𝐈{\boldsymbol{H}}_{N+1}\triangleq\mathbf{I} and 𝑫N≜𝐈≜subscript𝑫𝑁𝐈{\boldsymbol{D}}_{N}\triangleq\mathbf{I}. 𝒚=𝑹​(∏i=1N𝑫i​𝑯i)​𝒙1+𝒛𝒚𝑹superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑫𝑖subscript𝑯𝑖subscript𝒙1𝒛{\boldsymbol{y}}=\sqrt{{\boldsymbol{R}}}\left(\prod_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{D}}_{i}{\boldsymbol{H}}_{i}\right){\boldsymbol{x}}_{1}+{\boldsymbol{z}}

Since it can be shown that λmax​(𝑹)≐λmin​(𝑹)≐𝖲𝖭𝖱0approaches-limitsubscript𝜆𝑹subscript𝜆𝑹approaches-limitsuperscript𝖲𝖭𝖱0\lambda_{\max}({\boldsymbol{R}})\doteq\lambda_{\min}({\boldsymbol{R}})\doteq{\mathsf{SNR}}^{0}, the AF multihop channel is DMT-equivalent to the channel defined by

𝑯N​𝑫N−1​⋯​𝑯2​𝑫1​𝑯1,subscript𝑯𝑁subscript𝑫𝑁1⋯subscript𝑯2subscript𝑫1subscript𝑯1{\boldsymbol{H}}_{N}{\boldsymbol{D}}_{N-1}\cdots{\boldsymbol{H}}_{2}{\boldsymbol{D}}_{1}{\boldsymbol{H}}_{1},

Therefore, the multihop channel with the thus defined AF strategy is DMT-equivalent to a (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) Rayleigh product channel, i.e.,

dAF​(k)=∑i=k+1nminci.superscript𝑑AF𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑘1subscript𝑛subscript𝑐𝑖d^{\text{AF}}(k)=\sum_{i=k+1}^{n_{\min}}c_{i}.

In the rest of the paper, we identify the Rayleigh product channel, the AF multihop channel and the vector (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) when confusion is not likely.

IV-B A Variant : Project-and-Forward

We propose a new scheme called project-and-forward (PF), as shown in Fig. ​5. This scheme can be used only when full antenna cooperation within cluster is possible, that is, all antennas in the same cluster are controlled by a central unit. At the node #i𝑖i, the received signal is first projected to the signal subspace 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}, spanned by the columns of the channel matrix 𝑯¯isubscript¯𝑯𝑖\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{i}. The dimension of 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i} is risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}, the rank of 𝑯¯isubscript¯𝑯𝑖\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{i}. After the component-wise normalization, the projected signal is transmitted using risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} (out of nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}) antennas. It is now clear that 𝑯¯i+1∈ℂni+1×risubscript¯𝑯𝑖1superscriptℂsubscript𝑛𝑖1subscript𝑟𝑖\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{i+1}\in\mathbb{C}^{n_{i+1}\times r_{i}} is actually composed of the risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} columns of the previously defined 𝑯i+1subscript𝑯𝑖1{\boldsymbol{H}}_{i+1}, with r0≜n0≜subscript𝑟0subscript𝑛0r_{0}\triangleq n_{0}.

More precisely, the 𝑸¯i∈ℂni×risubscript¯𝑸𝑖superscriptℂsubscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}_{i}\in\mathbb{C}^{n_{i}\times r_{i}} is an orthogonal basis of 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i} with 𝑸¯i†​𝑸¯i=𝐈subscriptsuperscript¯𝑸†𝑖subscript¯𝑸𝑖𝐈{\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}}^{\scriptscriptstyle{\dagger}\!}_{i}\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}_{i}=\mathbf{I}. We can rewrite

𝑯¯i=𝑸¯i​𝑮¯isubscript¯𝑯𝑖subscript¯𝑸𝑖subscript¯𝑮𝑖\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{i}=\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}_{i}\underline{{\boldsymbol{G}}}_{i}

with 𝑮¯i∈ℂri×ri−1subscript¯𝑮𝑖superscriptℂsubscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖1\underline{{\boldsymbol{G}}}_{i}\in\mathbb{C}^{r_{i}\times r_{i-1}}. For simplicity, we let 𝑸¯isubscript¯𝑸𝑖\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}_{i} be obtained by the QR decomposition of 𝑯¯isubscript¯𝑯𝑖\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{i} if ni>ri−1subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖1n_{i}>r_{i-1} and be identity matrix if ni≤risubscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖n_{i}\leq r_{i}. The main idea of the PF scheme is not to use more antennas than necessary to forward the signal. Since the useful signal lies only in the risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}-dimensional signal subspace, the projection of the received signal provides sufficient statistics and reduces the noise power by a factor nirisubscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖\frac{n_{i}}{r_{i}}. In this case, only risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} antennas are needed to forward the projected signal. Let us define 𝑷i≜𝑫¯i​𝑸¯i†≜subscript𝑷𝑖subscript¯𝑫𝑖subscriptsuperscript¯𝑸†𝑖{\boldsymbol{P}}_{i}\triangleq\underline{{\boldsymbol{D}}}_{i}{\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}}^{\scriptscriptstyle{\dagger}\!}_{i}. Then, as in the AF case, the PF multihop channel is DMT-equivalent to the channel defined by

𝚷PF=𝑯¯N​𝑷N−1​⋯​𝑯¯2​𝑷1​𝑯¯1.subscript𝚷PFsubscript¯𝑯𝑁subscript𝑷𝑁1⋯subscript¯𝑯2subscript𝑷1subscript¯𝑯1{\boldsymbol{\Pi}}_{\text{PF}}=\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{N}{\boldsymbol{P}}_{N-1}\cdots\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{2}{\boldsymbol{P}}_{1}\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{1}.

The following theorem states that using only risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} out of nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} antennas to forward the projected signal does not incur any loss of diversity, as compared to the AF scheme.

Theorem 7

The PF multihop channel is DMT-equivalent to a (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) Rayleigh product channel.

While the PF and AF have the same diversity gain, the PF outperforms the AF in power gain for two reasons. One reason is, as stated before, that the projection reduces the average noise power. The other reason is that the accumulated noise in the AF case is more substantial than that in the PF case. This is because in the PF case, less relay antennas are used than in the AF case. Since the power of independent noises from different transmit antennas add up at the receiver side, the accumulated noise in the AF case “enjoys” a larger “transmit diversity order” than in the PF case. We call it the noise hardening effect. Some examples will be given in the section of numerical results.

IV-C Practical Issues

IV-C1 Space-Time Coding

From the input-output point of view, the multihop channel with AF/PF protocol is merely a linear MIMO fading channel, for which the DMT-achieving space-time codes exist. For example, in [11], a Gaussian code is shown to achieve the DMT of a n0×n1subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1n_{0}\times n_{1} Rayleigh channel if the code length l≥n0+n1−1𝑙subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛11l\geq n_{0}+n_{1}-1. This result can easily be extended to a general linear fading channel and one can show that Gaussian coding is DMT-achieving for any fading statistics if l𝑙l is large enough.

Another family of code construction is based on cyclic division algebra (CDA). These codes have minimum length n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} and are commonly known as the Perfect codes [12, 13]. They are DMT-achieving thanks to the so-called non-vanishing determinant (NVD) property. It has been shown that they are approximately universal [14, 13] since they are DMT-achieving for all fading statistics. Therefore, we propose to use the rate-n~0subscript~𝑛0\tilde{n}_{0} n0×n0subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛0n_{0}\times n_{0} Perfect codes. In this case, the only information that the source need to know is n~0subscript~𝑛0\tilde{n}_{0}.

IV-C2 Antenna Reduction

In the AF case, provided the number of total available antennas (n0,n1,…,nN)subscript𝑛0subscript𝑛1…subscript𝑛𝑁(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}), the vertical reduction result gives an exact number of necessary antennas at each node in the DMT sense. This result can be used to reduce the number of transmit and relay antennas444Reducing the number of receive antennas does not do any good, since more receive antennas always provide larger power gain without increasing the complexity.. If Perfect space-time codes are used, reducing the number of transmit antennas n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} means reducing the coding length, i.e., coding delay and decoding complexity, since the code length is equal to the number of transmit antennas. For instance, only two transmit antennas are needed in a (4,2,2,2)4222(4,2,2,2) channel. Therefore, instead of using a 4×4444\times 4 Perfect code the code length of which is 444, one can use the Golden code [15] of length 222 and still achieve the DMT.

In fact, less relay antennas also means less relay signaling (relay probing, synchronization, etc.) overhead especially when different antennas are from different relaying terminals (single-antenna relays). Furthermore, using more relay antennas hardens the relayed noise. This is the same phenomenon as we stated in the PF case. Therefore, the number of relay antennas at each node should be restricted to n¯¯𝑛\bar{n} (defined in (10)), the number given by the vertical reduction.

V Examples and Numerical Results

In this section, we provide some examples of multihop channels and show the performance of AF scheme with simulation results. In all cases, we make the same assumptions as in section II.

V-A Horizontal and Vertical Reduction

Outage performances versus the received SNR per node of different multihop channels are shown in Fig. ​7. Note that both the (2,2)22(2,2) and (2,2,2)222(2,2,2) channels are minimal and have diversity order 444 and 333, respectively. The (3,2,2)322(3,2,2) channel can be horizontally reduced to (2,2)22(2,2) and thus has diversity 444. Similarly, the (2,2,2,2)2222(2,2,2,2), (4,2,2,2)4222(4,2,2,2) and (8,2,2,2)8222(8,2,2,2) channels can be reduced to (2,2,2)222(2,2,2) and have diversity 333. As compared to the (2,2,2,2)2222(2,2,2,2) channel, the larger number of transmit antennas in the (8,2,2,2)8222(8,2,2,2) weakens the fading of the first hop and the performance is close to the (2,2,2)222(2,2,2) channel.

Another example is to illustrate the vertical reduction of multihop channels, as shown in Fig. ​8. We first consider the case of a (1,4,1)141(1,4,1) channel. The necessary antenna number n¯¯𝑛\bar{n} is 111 and the minimal vertical form is thus (1,1,1)111(1,1,1). We observe that, although both the (1,4,1)141(1,4,1) and (1,1,1)111(1,1,1) channels have diversity 111, a power gain of 777 dB is obtained at Pout=10−4subscript𝑃outsuperscript104P_{\text{out}}=10^{-4} by using only one relay antennas out of four, if the AF scheme is used. As stated in section IV-C2, the gain is due to avoiding the hardening of relayed noise. Then, we consider the (3,1,4,2)3142(3,1,4,2) channel. The necessary number of antennas n¯¯𝑛\bar{n} is 222 in this case. As shown in Fig. ​8, by restricting the number of relay antennas to 222, we have a (3,1,2,2)3122(3,1,2,2) channel and a gain of 222 dB is observered at Pout=10−4subscript𝑃outsuperscript104P_{\text{out}}=10^{-4}. We can further reduce the number of transmit antennas to 222 to get a (2,1,2,2)2122(2,1,2,2) channel. Unlike the reduction of relay antennas, the reduction of transmit antennas does not provide any gain because it does not affect the relayed noise. In contrast, it degrades the performance since the first hop (2,1)21(2,1) is faded more seriously than the original first hop (3,1)31(3,1). Nevertheless, the (2,1,2,2)2122(2,1,2,2) channel is still better than the (3,1,4,2)3142(3,1,4,2) channel and is only 0.70.70.7 dB from the (3,1,2,2)3122(3,1,2,2) channel.

V-B Project-and-Forward

In Fig. ​9, we compare the PF scheme with the AF scheme for the (1,2,1)121(1,2,1) and (1,3,2)132(1,3,2), respectively. First of all, note that the AF and the PF have the same diversity order, as predicted. Then, a power gain of 8.58.58.5 dB (respectively, 6.56.56.5 dB) over the AF scheme is obtained by the PF scheme in the (1,2,1)121(1,2,1) (respective, (1,3,2)132(1,3,2) channel). This is due to the maximum ratio combining (MRC) gain in the first hop and to avoiding the relayed noise hardening.

V-C Coded Performance

We now study the coded performance of the AF multihop channel. The performance measure is the symbol error rate (SER) versus the received SNR under the maximum likelihood (ML) decoding. We still take the (3,1,4,2)3142(3,1,4,2) channel as an example. Since n~0=1subscript~𝑛01\tilde{n}_{0}=1, the diagonal algebraic space-time (DAST) code555Note that the DAST code is the diagonal version of the rate-one Perfect code proposed in [12]. [16] can be used. As shown in Fig. ​10, with the DAST code, the symbol error rate performances of in the (3,1,4,2)3142(3,1,4,2), (3,1,2,2)3122(3,1,2,2) and (2,1,2,2)2122(2,1,2,2) channels have exactly the same behavior as the outage performances of the channels do Fig. ​8. Moreover, we can use the Alamouti code [17] for the (2,1,2,2)2122(2,1,2,2) channel. As we can see in the figure, the Alamouti code outperforms all the DAST codes with minimum delay and minimum decoding complexity. The potential benefits from the vertical reduction are thus highlighted.

V-D Multihop vs. Direct Transmission

Finally, we introduce the path loss model [18]

𝖲𝖭𝖱received∝distance−α​𝖲𝖭𝖱transmittedproportional-tosubscript𝖲𝖭𝖱receivedsuperscriptdistance𝛼subscript𝖲𝖭𝖱transmitted{\mathsf{SNR}}_{\text{received}}\propto\text{distance}^{-\alpha}{\mathsf{SNR}}_{\text{transmitted}}

where α𝛼\alpha is the path loss factor. We fix the distance from the source to the destination and dispose the relay nodes on the source-destination line with equal distance. Each node contains two antennas. We compare the 222-, 333- and 444-hop channel with the direct transmission (single-hop) channel. the performance measure is the transmitted power gain of the multihop channel over the single-hop channel at certain target outage probability (10−3superscript10310^{-3} and 10−4superscript10410^{-4}). The path loss factor α𝛼\alpha takes the typical values [18] 333, 3.53.53.5, and 444 for wireless channels. In Fig. ​11(a), the total transmission power in the multihop channel is considered. Power gain is obtained for α=3.5𝛼3.5\alpha=3.5 and 444. Then, the transmission power per node is considered in Fig. ​11(b). In this case, power gain is obtained for all α𝛼\alpha and is as high as 111111 dB. In practice, the transmission power per node also represents the interference level for other terminals which has a significant impact on the network capacity. In both figures, the power gain is lower at 10−4superscript10410^{-4} than at 10−3superscript10310^{-3}. This is due to the fact that the direct transmission channel is a 2×2222\times 2 Rayleigh channel and has diversity 444, while the multihop channel is (2,2,…,2)22…2(2,2,\ldots,2) and has diversity 333. And low diversity gain means decreasing power gain with increasing SNR or equivalently, with decreasing outage probability.

VI Conclusion

Perhaps the simplest relaying scheme in the MIMO multihop channel is the Amplify-and-Forward scheme. In part I of this paper, by identifying the AF multihop channel with the so-called Rayleigh product channel, we have obtained the complete characterization of the diversity-multiplexing tradeoff of the AF scheme in a multihop channel with arbitrary number of antennas and hops. The characterization is provided both in direct closed-form and recursive form. Based on the DMT, a number of properties of the AF multihop channel have been derived.

In the second part, we will show that the AF scheme is suboptimal in general, by establishing the diversity upper bound of the multihop channel with any relaying scheme. By partitioning the multihop channel into AF subchannels, we achieve the upper bound with both distributed and non-distributed schemes.

With the two preceding lemmas, we have the following lemma that provides the asymptotical pdf of 𝜶𝜶\boldsymbol{\alpha} conditionned on 𝜷𝜷\boldsymbol{\beta} in the high SNR regime.

Lemma 6
p​(𝜶|𝜷)≐{][c]l′s𝖲𝖭𝖱−E​(𝜶|𝜷),f​o​r​(α,β)∈R_α—β,𝖲𝖭𝖱−∞,o​t​h​e​r​w​i​s​e,p(\boldsymbol{\alpha}|\boldsymbol{\beta})\doteq\left\{\begin{IEEEeqnarraybox}[]{[}][c]{l^{\prime}s}{\mathsf{SNR}}^{-E(\boldsymbol{\alpha}|\boldsymbol{\beta})},&for$(\boldsymbol{\alpha},\boldsymbol{\beta})\in\mathcal{R}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}|\boldsymbol{\beta}}$,\\ {\mathsf{SNR}}^{-\infty},&otherwise,\end{IEEEeqnarraybox}\right. where

E​(𝜶|𝜷)≜∑i=1q(n+1−i)​αi+∑i=1q(i−n−1)​βi+∑j=1q∑i<j(αi−βj)++∑j=q+1m∑i=1q(αi−βj)+,≜𝐸conditional𝜶𝜷superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑞𝑛1𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑞𝑖𝑛1subscript𝛽𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑞subscript𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛽𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑞1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑞superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛽𝑗E(\boldsymbol{\alpha}|\boldsymbol{\beta})\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{q}(n+1-i)\alpha_{i}+\sum_{i=1}^{q}(i-n-1)\beta_{i}+\sum_{j=1}^{q}\sum_{i<j}(\alpha_{i}-\beta_{j})^{+}+\sum_{j=q+1}^{m}\sum_{i=1}^{q}(\alpha_{i}-\beta_{j})^{+}, (32)

and

ℛ𝜶|𝜷≜{α1≤…≤αq,β1≤…≤βm,andβi≤αi,fori=1,…,q}.\mathcal{R}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}|\boldsymbol{\beta}}\triangleq\left\{\alpha_{1}\leq\ldots\leq\alpha_{q},\ \beta_{1}\leq\ldots\leq\beta_{m},\ \text{and}\ \beta_{i}\leq\alpha_{i},\ \text{for}\ i=1,\ldots,q\right\}. (33)

For n≥m𝑛𝑚n\geq m, applying the variable changes to (19a), we have

if (𝜶,𝜷)∈ℛ(1)𝜶𝜷superscriptℛ1(\boldsymbol{\alpha},\boldsymbol{\beta})\in\mathcal{R}^{(1)} and p​(𝜶|𝜷)≐𝖲𝖭𝖱−∞approaches-limit𝑝conditional𝜶𝜷superscript𝖲𝖭𝖱p(\boldsymbol{\alpha}|\boldsymbol{\beta})\doteq{\mathsf{SNR}}^{-\infty} otherwise.

for (𝜶,𝜷)∈ℛ(2)𝜶𝜷superscriptℛ2(\boldsymbol{\alpha},\boldsymbol{\beta})\in\mathcal{R}^{(2)} and p​(𝜶|𝜷)≐𝖲𝖭𝖱−∞approaches-limit𝑝conditional𝜶𝜷superscript𝖲𝖭𝖱p(\boldsymbol{\alpha}|\boldsymbol{\beta})\doteq{\mathsf{SNR}}^{-\infty} otherwise. Combining the two cases, we prove the lemma. ∎

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 1

The following lemma will be used repeatedly in the most of the proofs.

B-B Solving the Optimization Problem

B-B1 Case 1 [nN+1<n~0subscript𝑛𝑁1subscript~𝑛0n_{N+1}<\tilde{n}_{0}]

Minimization of E​(𝜶,𝜶′)𝐸𝜶superscript𝜶′E(\boldsymbol{\alpha},\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}) of (42) with respect to (w.r.t.) 𝜶𝜶\boldsymbol{\alpha} can be decomposed into nminsubscript𝑛{n_{\min}} minimizations w.r.t. α1,…,αnminsubscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼subscript𝑛\alpha_{1},\ldots,\alpha_{{n_{\min}}} successively, i.e.,

min𝜶=minαnmin⁡⋯​minα1.subscript𝜶subscriptsubscript𝛼subscript𝑛⋯subscriptsubscript𝛼1\min_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}=\min_{\alpha_{n_{\min}}}\cdots\min_{\alpha_{1}}.

We start with α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1}. From (33), the feasible region of α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1} is 0≤α1≤α1′0subscript𝛼1subscriptsuperscript𝛼′10\leq\alpha_{1}\leq\alpha^{\prime}_{1}. Since the only α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1}-related term in (42) is (c1−nN+1)​α1subscript𝑐1subscript𝑛𝑁1subscript𝛼1(c_{1}-n_{N+1})\alpha_{1} and c1−nN+1>0subscript𝑐1subscript𝑛𝑁10c_{1}-n_{N+1}>0 for nN+1<n~0subscript𝑛𝑁1subscript~𝑛0n_{N+1}<\tilde{n}_{0}, we have α1∗=0superscriptsubscript𝛼10\alpha_{1}^{*}=0. Now, suppose that the minimization w.r.t. α1,…,αj−1subscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝑗1\alpha_{1},\ldots,\alpha_{j-1} is done and that we would like to minimize w.r.t. αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j}. For αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j}, j≤nmin′𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑛′j\leq n^{\prime}_{\min}, we set the initial region as

0≤α1′≤⋯≤αj−1′≤αj≤αj′0subscriptsuperscript𝛼′1⋯subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑗1subscript𝛼𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑗0\leq\alpha^{\prime}_{1}\leq\cdots\leq\alpha^{\prime}_{j-1}\leq\alpha_{j}\leq\alpha^{\prime}_{j}

in which we have ∑i<j(αi′−αj)+=0subscript𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑖subscript𝛼𝑗0\sum_{i<j}{(\alpha^{\prime}_{i}-\alpha_{j})}^{\scriptscriptstyle+}=0. The feasibility conditions in (40) require that αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j} must not go right across αj′subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑗\alpha^{\prime}_{j}. The only choice is therefore to go to the left. Each time αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j} goes across an αi′subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑖\alpha^{\prime}_{i} from the right to the left, (αi′−αj)+superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑖subscript𝛼𝑗(\alpha^{\prime}_{i}-\alpha_{j})^{+} increases by αi′−αjsubscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑖subscript𝛼𝑗\alpha^{\prime}_{i}-\alpha_{j}, which increases the coefficient of αi′subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑖\alpha^{\prime}_{i} by 111 and decreases the coefficient of αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j} by 111. It can be shown that, to minimize the value of E​(𝜶,𝜶′)𝐸𝜶superscript𝜶′E(\boldsymbol{\alpha},\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}) w.r.t. αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j}, αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j} is allowed to cross αi′subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑖\alpha^{\prime}_{i} only when the current coefficient of αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j} in (42) is positive777When the coefficient of αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i} in (42) is positive, decreasing αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i} decreases E​(𝜶,𝜶′)𝐸𝜶superscript𝜶′E(\boldsymbol{\alpha},\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}).. So, αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j} stops moving only in the following two cases : 1) it hits the left extreme, 00; and 2) its coefficient achieves 00 when it is in the interval [αk′,αk+1′]subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑘1[\alpha^{\prime}_{k},\alpha^{\prime}_{k+1}] for some k<j𝑘𝑗k<j. Same reasoning applies to αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j} for j>nmin′𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑛′j>n^{\prime}_{\min}, except that the initial region is set to 0≤α1′≤⋯≤αnmin′′≤αj0subscriptsuperscript𝛼′1⋯subscriptsuperscript𝛼′subscriptsuperscript𝑛′subscript𝛼𝑗0\leq\alpha^{\prime}_{1}\leq\cdots\leq\alpha^{\prime}_{n^{\prime}_{\min}}\leq\alpha_{j}.

Therefore, the optimization problem can be solved by counting the total number of freed αi′subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑖\alpha^{\prime}_{i}’s. As shown in Fig. ​6(a), when j𝑗j is small, the initial coefficient of αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j} is large and thus αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j} can free out αj−1′,…,α1′subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑗1…subscriptsuperscript𝛼′1\alpha^{\prime}_{j-1},\ldots,\alpha^{\prime}_{1}. We have αj∗=0superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑗0\alpha_{j}^{*}=0, which corresponds to the first stopping condition. For large j𝑗j, the initial coefficient of αjsubscript𝛼𝑗\alpha_{j} is not large enough and only αj−1′,…,αg​(j)′subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑗1…subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑔𝑗\alpha^{\prime}_{j-1},\ldots,\alpha^{\prime}_{g(j)} is freed, which corresponds to the second stopping condition. With the above reasoning, we can get g​(j)𝑔𝑗g(j)

g​(j)={][c]l′sj−1−(j−1−nN+1+cj)+1,f​o​r​j≤n’_min,nN+1−cj+1,f​o​r​j¿n’_min.g(j)=\left\{\begin{IEEEeqnarraybox}[]{[}][c]{l^{\prime}s}j-1-(j-1-n_{N+1}+c_{j})+1,&for$j\leq n'_{\min}$,\\ n_{N+1}-c_{j}+1,&for$j>n'_{\min}$.\end{IEEEeqnarraybox}\right. (44)

From (44) and (7), we get

B-C Proof of Theorem 6

To prove the first case, we use induction on N𝑁N. Suppose that it is true for N𝑁N, which means that the joint pdf of 𝜶​(𝚷g​𝚷g†)𝜶subscript𝚷𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝚷†𝑔\boldsymbol{\alpha}({\boldsymbol{\Pi}}_{g}{{\boldsymbol{\Pi}}}^{\scriptscriptstyle{\dagger}\!}_{g}) is the same as that of 𝜶​(𝚷​𝚷†)𝜶𝚷superscript𝚷†\boldsymbol{\alpha}({\boldsymbol{\Pi}}{{\boldsymbol{\Pi}}}^{\scriptscriptstyle{\dagger}\!}). Furthermore, we know by lemma 8 that 𝜶​(𝚷g​𝑻N,N+1​𝑻N,N+1†​𝚷g†)=𝜶​(𝚷g​𝚷g†)𝜶subscript𝚷𝑔subscript𝑻𝑁𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝑻𝑁𝑁1†subscriptsuperscript𝚷†𝑔𝜶subscript𝚷𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝚷†𝑔\boldsymbol{\alpha}({\boldsymbol{\Pi}}_{g}{\boldsymbol{T}}_{N,N+1}{{\boldsymbol{T}}_{N,N+1}}^{\scriptscriptstyle{\dagger}\!}{{\boldsymbol{\Pi}}}^{\scriptscriptstyle{\dagger}\!}_{g})=\boldsymbol{\alpha}({\boldsymbol{\Pi}}_{g}{{\boldsymbol{\Pi}}}^{\scriptscriptstyle{\dagger}\!}_{g}). Same steps as (38)(39) complete the proof.

To prove the second statement, we perform a singular value decomposition on the matrices 𝑻i,i+1subscript𝑻𝑖𝑖1{\boldsymbol{T}}_{i,i+1}’s and then apply the first statement.

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 2 and Theorem 3

C-A Proof of Theorem 2

C-A1 The Direct Part

The direct part is to show that, if pN−1≤N−1subscript𝑝𝑁1𝑁1p_{N-1}\leq N-1, then (56) is true. C-B Proof of Theorem 3
